I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was amazing and incredibly helpful in studying out of class
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is an outstanding TF. Explains concepts very well and is always available to meet in person or via email.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was an incredible TA, and I hope she will consider teaching the class so future generations of FES students can have the benefit of this unique and excellent course.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Offering multiple review session and off site opportunities to interact.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Very strong. Extremely knowledgeable in all concepts related to taxonomy.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is really an excellent teacher and made field trips engaging. I learned a lot from her.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is an extremely knowledgeable teaching assistant, and is responsive to student concerns. She was the best, most prepared TA I have yet had at Yale, and could easily teach a version of this course.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Personable, accessible and enthusiastic about the subject matter. Marlyse was interested in making class fun for all of us. She was present and engaged. Her peer or near-peer approach was appropriate for the set of students electing to take this course. When unsure of something, Marlyse was willing to do additional research and get back to us.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was overall an organized TA who really knew the course material well and made herself available to students when needed. Despite living far from campus and having other obligations, she made time for the students and was flexible in her scheduling to meet the students' needs. I thought she was a little set in her ways and sometimes it was hard for students to voice their opinions or ideas and feel like there was space for those to be heard. In that respect, sometimes I felt like we were being lectured at a little too much and their was little room for discussion. I think she could improve her teaching by giving more time for questions and discussion among the students and spending a little less time talking and informing the students. In addition, sometimes I felt like when she wasn't sure the answer to a question asked by a student, her response gave off an air that such knowledge was not really important or that because she didn't know the answer it wasn't important. Despite this, I appreciated her guidance and knowledge and would recommend the class to others if she was the teaching assistant in the future.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Great class. However a little nervous about the final and what material will be on it
Understanding the concepts of dendrology is extremely important for anyone interested in the environment and or forestry.

I felt like there were a few too many field trips and they really slowed towards the end of the semester. I think we could have all used a couple more lectures on the slide material (which we were ultimately responsible for on the final). The readings were too dense to read outside of class without discussions/lectures with the instructors.

In terms of field trips (Q's 8-10) I really appreciated how field-oriented the class was. Within a schedule involving many lectures and classroom-based learning, this class was exactly what I needed to remind me of how much learning can be done outside and why the field of ecology is so interesting to me. I felt I learned an incredible amount about class material, tree identification, as well as important habitats and habitat structure within CT through this course. All of these were learned to a higher degree than would have been via memorization in a classroom. Spending all classes doing hands-on learning was very important to me and I would strongly suggest a continuation of this approach as much as possible in the future. However, I think that it does mean that some of the textbook and lecture material regarding taxonomy and natural history of trees and ecological communities in the area is not learned as well. Because these concepts are more up to the students to learn on their own time, for me, at least, it was difficult to make the time to study and internalize these on my own when there was no time or place to discuss the material with other students. I wish there had been some optional classes in addition to the regular weekly meeting to go over the material that was not covered in the field. I would hope such opportunities would be available for future students. In terms of the instructor (Q's 11-13) I did not feel like I really had time to get to know her and so it was hard to become familiar with her teaching style. I felt like the TA took on much of the teaching in the class. It was clear that Professor Camp is very knowledgeable about forest ecology and I wish there had been more of an opportunity to absorb that. Similar to the TA, I felt like she was a little set in her ways and had an agenda to accomplish which sometimes got in the way of my learning and curiosity.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: All of them
Field trips on tuesdays
Fieldwork
Most of the field trips were excellent and illuminating!
The field trips were an extremely helpful way to learn about tree identification in the field. They were far and away the best aspect of this course.
Field trips in a small group. Getting to know the other students, instructor and teaching assistant.

The best aspect of this course was getting to travel to a new place each week and spend 2-3 hours wandering around the woods, getting a feel for the flora of different habitats within the relatively small area of southern Connecticut.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Prep for the final
none
As I said above, less field trips and a few more lectures, interspersed.

The course takes a "flipped classroom" approach in the sense that there are a series of lectures that are asked about on the final exam but are never actually discussed in class. It's not really flipped, however, because not only are lectures not reviewed but none of the material covered in these lectures is discussed at any point during the semester. This makes studying for the final exam extremely challenging. A few of the late semester field trips should be replaced with more traditional in-class lectures.

It was difficult to determine which reading to do when. Break the reading list into week-by-week assignments and reinforce with class discussion (while in the field or while traveling to the field) or weekly single question quizzes (even verbal quizzes that don't really matter).

I think finding a way to continue to go into the field as much as possible while still communicating the information in the lectures and allowing more opportunities for student discussion would help this course. Personally, I would have benefited from a little more time to ourselves in the woods to look at things and test our knowledge or to really know a plant and not feel like we had a strict agenda we had to follow.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: not relevant
Again, break the lectures up by week and reinforce with class discussion.
I did find this relationship hard to navigate (see comment in Q 16).

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Really important to be an MF and understand trees
I came away from this class with outstanding knowledge of taxonomy of New England flora. This is particularly relevant to my work in conservation management.
One of the best things about this class is the mix of students that choose to take it - including MF, SOM, Architecture, College, etc.

This course is important to me because it has allowed me to become familiar with a wide variety of habitats in Connecticut and by extrapolation northern hardwood forests in the Eastern United States. It also allowed me to see how species of tree and shrub here fit into the bigger picture of the vegetation of the world, and how they interact with each other. Finally, it allowed me to spend time outside observing the world and paying close attention to small details that I may not have noticed without this course. I feel this class was a good lesson in observation that will be helpful in any career I choose down the road, especially one that is related to ecology or conservation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn trees
Develop better understanding of plant relationships.
To provide myself with foundational knowledge for working in New England forests.
I love trees. And the outdoor orientation of the course provides a welcome change from classroom courses.

I took this course because I had some background in the material and wanted to gain a new outlook on it. I have spent a lot of time wandering around woods and other habitats, but this class provided a new, academic way of being in the woods that I had not experienced before. The class was also a wonderfully relaxing, yet stimulating sanctuary from the traditional classroom setting and I was very grateful for that.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes I know a million percent more about trees
beyond my expectations
I learned taxonomy is a lot more memorization than logic. If you haven't seen something before, it will be difficult to place it.

I felt the class was a little too focused on tree ID and I did not learn as much about taxonomy and natural history as I would have liked to. I would have enjoyed learning more about the uses of different trees both historically and currently and how habitats have changed over time. Also more focus on what the presence and form of a tree tells one about the landscape.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Helpful to study with others

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep on top of the slides
It is an excellent course too bad you will not get to have Ann Camp as your teacher.
Its entirely self-paced. Divide up the lectures and readings throughout the semester to maximize adsorption. Get to know your professor, TA and classmates.

I would advise them to spend as much time outside practicing what they learn in class as possible. Also, becoming familiar with latin names, families, and orders early on would be helpful. And just enjoy the time outside in these beautiful places!
